verses.text: The Lord appeared to Abraham by the oaks of Mamre, while he was sitting at the entrance of his tent during the heat of the day.
verses.comment: God appears visibly to Abraham, foreshadowing later divine visitations (see Ex 3:2; John 1:14). The location at Mamre is significant for the development of Abraham’s covenant.

verses.text: He looked up and saw three men standing nearby. When he saw them, he ran from the tent entrance to meet them and bowed down to the ground.
verses.comment: The three visitors have long been seen as a profound mystery—many Church Fathers saw here an early image of the Trinity. Abraham’s humility and hospitality foreshadow Christian virtues (see Heb 13:2).

verses.text: He said, 'My Lord, if I have found favor in your sight, do not pass by your servant.'
verses.comment: Abraham’s address as 'My Lord' may imply recognition of his guests’ supernatural character. Hospitality is shown to God and His messengers.

verses.text: Please let a little water be brought so you may wash your feet, and rest yourselves under the tree.
verses.comment: Foot washing symbolizes humility and service, prefiguring Christ’s own action (compare John 13:5).

verses.text: Let me bring a little bread, so you may refresh yourselves. After that, you may continue on, now that you have come to your servant.' They replied, 'Do as you have said.'
verses.comment: Sharing a meal was an act of covenant fellowship—a theme fulfilled in the Eucharistic bread Christ gives (see Luke 24:30).

verses.text: So Abraham hurried into the tent to Sarah and said, 'Quick! Take three measures of fine flour, knead it, and make cakes.'
verses.comment: The large amount of bread reveals great generosity. The preparation echoes bread offerings and points ahead to multiplication of bread (cf. Matt 14:19).

verses.text: Then Abraham ran to the herd, took a tender and good calf, gave it to a servant, who hurried to prepare it.
verses.comment: Bringing the best for guests anticipates later animal sacrifices, and ultimately, the offering of Christ, the spotless lamb (see 1 Cor 5:7).

verses.text: He took curds, milk, and the calf that he had prepared, and set it before them. He stood by them under the tree as they ate.
verses.comment: God partakes in a human meal—an early sign of God's closeness, which finds fulfillment when Christ dines with His people.

verses.text: They said to him, 'Where is Sarah, your wife?' He said, 'She is in the tent.'
verses.comment: The angelic visitors’ knowledge reveals their supernatural identity; the narrative now focuses on Sarah’s promised role.

verses.text: Then one of them said, 'I will surely return to you about this time next year, and Sarah your wife will have a son.' Sarah was listening at the tent door behind him.
verses.comment: The promise of a miraculous birth for Sarah parallels the later miraculous conceptions (compare Luke 1:34-37); God's plan often unfolds through divine intervention.

verses.text: Now Abraham and Sarah were old, advanced in age; and it had ceased to be with Sarah as with women.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the impossibility, humanly speaking, of Sarah having children—a recurring theme of God acting beyond natural limitations (Rom 4:19).

verses.text: So Sarah laughed to herself, saying, 'After I am worn out, and my lord is old, shall I have pleasure?'
verses.comment: Sarah’s laughter is doubting, yet mixes hope with disbelief. Her address of Abraham as 'my lord' is cited as an example of respect (see 1 Pet 3:6).

verses.text: The Lord said to Abraham, 'Why did Sarah laugh and say, "Shall I indeed bear a child, now that I am old?"'
verses.comment: God’s omniscience is shown—He hears Sarah’s unspoken thoughts, and gently corrects her doubt. This sets the stage for faith in God’s Word.

verses.text: 'Is anything too difficult for the Lord? At the appointed time I will return to you, about this time next year, and Sarah shall have a son.'
verses.comment: Here God affirms His omnipotence, a core doctrine repeated in later miraculous births and in Christ’s own Resurrection.

verses.text: But Sarah denied it, saying, 'I did not laugh,' because she was afraid. He said, 'No, but you did laugh.'
verses.comment: Sarah’s response demonstrates both human weakness and God’s gentle firmness—God’s ways are not thwarted by human doubt.

verses.text: Then the men got up from there, and looked toward Sodom. Abraham went with them to set them on their way.
verses.comment: Abraham’s continued presence shows his favored status and coming mediation for Sodom, a role prefiguring priestly intercession.

verses.text: The Lord said, 'Shall I hide from Abraham what I am about to do?'
verses.comment: God’s disclosure reveals a developing relationship—Abraham as a friend and partner in God’s plan, anticipating the intimacy of God with His saints.

verses.text: For Abraham will surely become a great and powerful nation, and all the nations of the earth will be blessed through him.
verses.comment: Reaffirms the universal blessing through Abraham, fulfilled ultimately in Christ and His Church (Gal 3:16).

verses.text: For I have known him, so that he may command his children and his household after him to keep the way of the Lord, by doing righteousness and justice, so that the Lord may bring upon Abraham what he has spoken about him.'
verses.comment: God invites Abraham to be the example of covenant fidelity through his household—a theme fulfilled in the calling of Christian families to pass on the faith.

verses.text: Then the Lord said, 'Because the outcry against Sodom and Gomorrah is great, and their sin is very grievous,
verses.comment: God hears the cry of the oppressed, foreshadowing later divine judgments and the prophetic call to righteousness.

verses.text: 'I will go down and see if they have done altogether according to the outcry that has reached Me; and if not, I will know.'
verses.comment: God’s investigative action reflects both perfect justice and mercy—a reminder that divine judgment is never arbitrary.

verses.text: So the men turned from there and went toward Sodom, but Abraham stood before the Lord.
verses.comment: Abraham’s persistent intercession points to the power of prayer and foreshadows the role of mediators on behalf of others before God.

verses.text: Abraham approached and said, 'Will You indeed sweep away the righteous with the wicked?'
verses.comment: This appeal stresses God’s justice. Abraham’s intercession serves as a model for bold but humble prayer.

verses.text: 'Suppose there are fifty righteous within the city. Will you indeed sweep it away and not forgive the place for the sake of the fifty righteous who are in it?'
verses.comment: Abraham appeals to God’s mercy through the presence of the righteous. Old Testament prayers often appeal on behalf of a faithful remnant.

verses.text: Far be it from you to do such a thing, to kill the righteous with the wicked, so that the righteous fare as the wicked! Far be that from you! Shall not the Judge of all the earth do what is just?'
verses.comment: This bold prayer affirms God as the just Judge of all. God’s justice and mercy are always in perfect harmony.

verses.text: The Lord said, 'If I find fifty righteous people within the city of Sodom, then I will forgive the whole place for their sake.'
verses.comment: God’s willingness to spare the whole for the sake of a few prefigures the concept of corporate solidarity—groundwork for understanding the role of saints in intercession.

verses.text: Abraham answered, 'See now, I have taken it upon myself to speak to the Lord, I who am but dust and ashes.'
verses.comment: Abraham’s humility before God is exemplary; true intercession does not come from pride, but from recognizing our own lowliness.

verses.text: 'Suppose five of the fifty righteous are lacking—will you destroy the whole city for lack of five?' He said, 'I will not destroy it if I find forty-five there.'
verses.comment: The persistent reduction shows Abraham’s growing boldness, and God’s unfailing mercy toward the smallest remnant of righteousness.

verses.text: He spoke to him again, and said, 'Suppose forty are found there.' He said, 'I will not do it for the sake of forty.'
verses.comment: God’s mercy continues to be extended with each request—an encouragement for patient, persevering prayer.

verses.text: Then he said, 'Oh let not the Lord be angry, and I will speak. Suppose thirty are found there.' He answered, 'I will not do it if I find thirty there.'
verses.comment: Each plea reveals the patience of God with the faithful intercessor—a biblical support for seeking God’s mercy for others.

verses.text: He said, 'Behold, I have taken it upon myself to speak to the Lord. Suppose twenty are found there.' He said, 'For the sake of twenty I will not destroy it.'
verses.comment: Abraham’s reverence, even as he persists, shows both awe before God and bold confidence in His mercy.

verses.text: Then he said, 'Oh let not the Lord be angry, and I will speak just once more. Suppose ten are found there.' He said, 'For the sake of ten I will not destroy it.'
verses.comment: Final reduction shows the extent of God’s mercy, and the power of righteous individuals. In Church tradition, the prayers of the righteous continue to avail much (cf. Jas 5:16).

verses.text: The Lord went His way, as soon as He had finished speaking with Abraham, and Abraham returned to his place.
verses.comment: The dialogue ends with God’s sovereignty and Abraham’s trusting return. This closes one of the most intimate divine-human conversations in the Old Testament, prefiguring the mediating role given to the leaders and spiritual elders throughout salvation history.
